Powering lending for main street entrepreneurs.

The following is an interview between Daniel McAuley, Co-Founder of Wharton FinTech, and Evan Baehr, co-founder of Able Lending. This interview took place February 16, 2015.

Tell us about Able.

Our mission is to ‘power the Fortune five million’, which refers to the five million small businesses who would never be able to raise venture capital or equity financing. Currently, most of financing options for this group of small businesses come with interest rates over 50% through alternative products like merchant cash advances. Able sits in the chasm between traditional nonprofit social enterprise lending and traditional high rate lenders.

Able is a non-bank non-depository lender. Our loans require that the borrower raise 25% of the capital towards their loan from three to five people, called their backers. This subordination structure allows us to always provide a lower interest rate to our borrowers compared to other lenders.

What is Able’s competitive advantage versus traditional lenders?

We have seen a massive erosion of community banks alongside major consolidation of the big banks. There were roughly 100,000 banking institutions about 100 years ago, while today there are about 5,000. The Dallas Fed reports that around 80% of deposits are held in the top ten financial institutions. All of this makes the government nervous about consumer protection, so they tighten underwriting restrictions on the banks. This allows new entrants (without bank charters) to capture all sorts of value that the banks are no longer able to capture.

There are two critical things that an alternative lender specifically must do. The first is to acquire customers, in this case, borrowers, at a reasonable cost. The second is to access lending capital to fund loans, because you don’t have deposits. Our structure of having friends and family in the loan gives us a competitive advantage in achieving those two components.

First, we lower acquisition costs by making all of our loans public. We create beautiful content to broadcast every loan so our borrowers post and share that information. That is a very bizarre behavior to pull off in the lending market because most ecosystems and products create an experience in which people are embarrassed to have borrowed money. When we make it public and have the five backers in the loan, those people can share in the success in the funding of that loan, generating tens of thousands of free impressions for Able.

The second is to attract lending capital at a reasonable rate. So far, capital providers love the 25% subordinated tranche in our loans because anticipated loss rates on the portfolio are very low. And that’s a structure not built on lending to extremely creditworthy borrowers or to various established businesses. That’s something that results only from the structure we have to the loan itself.

Let's talk about data. How does Able plan to innovate using data in underwriting decisions?

When developing Able we assumed that many companies were trying to innovate on underwriting itself. But it turns out that the institutional players are very suspicious of innovation in underwriting. So when we are out trying to raise lending capital, our message must be that we are not even attempting to innovate in underwriting. What we’ve found is that the market is very suspicious of using nontraditional big data for underwriting because we have over fifty years of historical data in the United States through multiple business cycles that has led banks to build very sound, very predictable and very accurate underwriting models.

In the case of Able, we do see some interesting data on the backers of our borrowers’ loans. We’re able to examine credit data of the backers so that we can understand more about you as a borrower and over time we can understand more about you and your credit risk based on the kind of people that you bring into your deal. However, it’s a really important distinction to understand that when you train your model on historical data you can only do so on the data and variables that you have access to. The process of introducing, testing and analyzing new data considerations takes up to a full business cycle to determine if these variables are significant. So you might not know if new variables are increasing the lift of a credit model for up to ten years. The proposition that people are really innovating in underwriting is one we have found is not very persuasive in the market, particularly for lending capital.

One of your competitors, OnDeck Capital, recently IPOed. How do you think this has impacted the small business lending sector and what does this mean for Able?

The OnDeck and Lending Club IPOs were both great in terms of capital markets. They invited dozens, probably hundreds of new institutions into the space. The data that came out in those S1’s is interesting for everybody and a few points jumped out. I believe that OnDeck’s average interest rate was about 56%, which in every single state is actually usurious and illegal to charge. It’s not that OnDeck is breaking the law that is interesting. To me it’s interesting that OnDeck, this sexy, amazing FinTech company backed by Midas-list VC’s is charging rates that most people think of as rates charged by payday lenders. To add insult to injury, their margins aren’t even very healthy. We think that their rates are driven by smaller dollar loans over very short terms with high default rates and extremely high acquisition costs. When you put those things together it’s a race to the top to drive interest rates up. This leads to an adverse credit selection effect whereby only unhealthy businesses choose to seek that kind of capital because they can’t access it at a lower rate elsewhere.

The other thing coming out of the S1’s is the reliance on brokers, which are these networks of totally wildcard, unknown quantities that have the leads. So Lending Club and OnDeck are doing everything they can to build out sales teams and better direct mail campaigns. However, they can’t shake their huge reliance on broker networks, which is a huge problem for them because they end up paying up to six percent of the loan amount to the broker in the form of a fee.

How do you think MBAs can add the most value as full-time employees or interns at FinTech startups?

These are two specific pieces of advice that Chris Cox, the VP or Product at Facebook gave to a set of MBAs when I was there. First, get very good at data. Many MBAs are expected to know Excel and how to build models and how to run regressions. In a startup, MBAs may be looked at to perform analysis and make decisions about which products to launch, or evaluate conversion funnels and various marketing campaigns. It is also helpful to learn about SQL and how is data stored and accessed so that you know how to query data to perform analysis and make suggestions yourself. The last thing you want to do as an MBA is make requests of the dev team; trust me, they are already rolling their eyes enough! Second, learn about design. In general, MBAs have a very bad aesthetic. We’re comfortable with Excel and legal documents but developing an appreciation of aesthetics and learning practical skills around the execution of design are both important. The practical execution side involves being conversant in Photoshop, being able to manipulate images and make changes in things like marketing campaigns and landing page optimization.

At FinTech companies, I think MBAs fall into one of two categories. You may be in the substance of the financial analysis that the company is doing, so you understand asset allocation, or consumer credit underwriting, or commercial credit underwriting, or options trading. If you really understand the math that’s driving the product then you can come in working on product, you can join the credit team, you could be on an operations team. If you don’t understand that, then your more natural areas to fit in would be business development or operations of any type, such as borrower operations or lending operations. Marketing is also an area where MBAs with training around data analytics can be very helpful in FinTech companies. Being very comfortable designing and running tests of many variants of ads across Google Adwords, Google Display and Facebook, and being able to infer from those results things about product positioning and messaging around your product is extremely valuable. Then there are some interesting components of business development and capital market formation where your previous experience could be directly helpful to a FinTech startup navigating that world. So if a company relies on hedge funds or other specific institutional investors as core partners, then someone working in business development who brings in those relationships could be helpful to a FinTech company.

Any final comments?

Overall, I am curious to know how alternative lenders will make any money. It seems that the underlying products are commodities; terms loan, MCA, unsecured consumer, etc. The underlying credit models are not only the same models, they are also relying on the same data from the same bureaus. The acquisition costs are so high that most lenders lose money on every loan they fund. They are all working to develop the same acquisition channels of direct mail, digital marketing, inside sales, broker relationships and other partner relationships like bank referrals. They’re also all running after many of the same providers of lending capital, and because these products are commoditized, the providers are always going to go to where the cheaper rate is. In that sense I find it hard to understand how many, or maybe even any, of these companies will actually make money at the end of the day. When Lending Club makes a comment that part of the IPO rationale was to raise a war chest so that they could build a nationally known brand, and that national brand awareness was possibly critical to bringing down the cost of acquisition of consumer borrowers, then the business that all of these companies are getting into is the same business that brick and mortar banks are in--which is national brand awareness. So it’s scary to me that it may not be about the credit model and it may not be about the product—rather, it’s all about the marketing optimization. I think that many people would not go start FinTech companies if they knew that the main thing they’re trying to do is increase the open rates of direct mail.

Now, you might say, well then why are we building Able? To us, Able is the only lender that has even the condition for the possibility of a differentiated product, which gives us a chance at pursuing the monopoly product position that Peter Thiel talked about in his most recent book. It all comes back to this reality: if everyone else has a commoditized loan product, we’re the only one that had created a non-commodity option—actually a fundamentally different underlying product which enables us to have different strategies for customer acquisitions and debt capital markets development. At this stage we clearly do not know if our loan structure works. We may not know that for years, but we at least know that we have a chance of a differentiated strategy in which our margins do not go to zero. And that is not something that I can say conclusively about any other alternative lender of which we are aware.

fields.description: Steve Weiner discusses the current cyber threat environment, the investment trends in cybersecurity companies and recommends cybersecurity solutions for FinTech entrepreneurs.
fields.title: Protect Your Assets: Cybersecurity + FinTech
fields.text:
When my submarine would dive beneath the waves, we’d lose the ability to communicate with the outside world and the crew would work diligently to avoid making excessive noise to prevent being detected. Nicknamed the “Silent Service”, the submarine force fosters a culture that is intensely focused on preserving operational security and cybersecurity. We undergo rigorous background checks and conduct continuous training to ensure that we are ready to combat emerging threats to our networks. But despite its cultural acceptance of cybersecurity, the Navy hasn’t been immune from cyber attacks,, which should be a cause for concern for any other organization that is trying to protect their digital assets. Since leaving the military, I’ve been amazed by my peers’ lack of awareness of cyber threats, for example, how easy it is to become complacent with information in the era of cloud computing (I’m composing this article in Google Docs). So it’s easy to understand why an entrepreneur wouldn’t have any concern with putting the company’s information in the cloud instead of implementing potentially higher cost and more secure enterprise network solutions. However, according to the UK’s Federation of Small Businesses, only two-fifths of over 1,200 small businesses surveyed in the UK were skeptical about the benefits of cloud computing compared to the security tradeoffs.

For FinTech companies, cybersecurity should be a top priority. According to the SEC, “at least 88 percent of broker-dealers and 74 percent of advisers have been the target of cyberattacks” and banks - such as JPMorgan - are spending a lot of money to beef up their cyber defense, and small business owners or startups are just as susceptible to looming cyber threats, but may be slow to adopt new security protocols. We want to arm FinTech entrepreneurs with the information that they need to safely operate their businesses, while highlighting some of the industry’s innovations and trends.

Wharton Cybersecurity Event

In an effort to raise awareness about cyber threats in the finance industry, Wharton FinTech recently welcomed Juliet Okafor, Global Director of Business Development and Marketing at Trushield Security Solutions. Trushield is a global cybersecurity company that provides comprehensive network and data security, risk management and compliance solutions to Fortune 500 companies, government agencies and international organizations that need to protect sensitive data or meet information technology security mandates. The discussion with Ms. Okafor was highly interactive and geared toward FinTech entrepreneurs who are looking to strike the right balance between growing their startup and protecting against imminent cyber threats. According to Ted Schlein, a veteran investor at Kleiner Perkins with several cybersecurity deals under his belt, “there are two types of companies: those that know they’ve been breached, and those that haven’t figured it out yet.” Furthermore, we at Wharton FinTech want to highlight the importance of admitting a breach. “It is my belief that companies that have been hacked can be further broken down to those that have come clean to the public about their breaches and those that haven’t,” says Daniel McAuley, Wharton FinTech Co-Founder. “It’s an incredibly important distinction, because the sooner a company comes clean about an attack, the sooner the cybersecurity industry can innovate to neutralize new threats. Sharing details about previous vulnerabilities doesn’t expose a company to further attacks. It makes everyone else stronger. This is one of the aims of the cybersecurity bill passed by the Senate last week. However, even if this bill becomes law, it remains to be seen if it will be strong enough to create open corporate information-sharing environment.”

While investing in cybersecurity software and hardware solutions can be expensive, the return on investment can provide peace of mind to an entrepreneur - but it’s not all about throwing more money at the problem. “Procedures and policies need to be in place and can contribute to a better overall awareness and company culture of protecting proprietary information,” said Ms. Okafor. She also likened cybersecurity protocols to having brakes on a car: “brakes allow a car to travel faster and slow down if necessary. Cybersecurity protects a company’s assets so it can innovate and grow.”

The Future of Security

The silver lining in the cyber threat cloud (excuse the pun) is that there is strong competition in the market for cybersecurity and investment dollars are flooding into the space. According to CB Insights, over $7 billion dollars have funded over 1,000deals over the last five years and investment is steadily increasing.

Lucas Nelson, a Principal with Gotham Ventures and co-author of The Art of Software Security Testing, recently outlined the cultural and technological themes that are transforming the cybersecurity market. “The first cultural trend comes from the admission that no system is truly secure,” Mr. Nelson writes, citing the resignation of Target CEO Gregg Steinhafel as an example. Secondly, security breaches, such as the ones that occurred at Target and JPMorgan, and even the US Navy example mentioned earlier, are often caused by malevolent outsiders, but the privacy issues at the NSA that were unveiled by Edward Snowden have caused ordinary citizens to take pause and government officials to direct efforts toward insider threats. According to Mr. Nelson, the technological trends that are driving cybersecurity innovation are cloud security and the Internet of Things, but “security has always lagged behind new technologies” and data migration to the cloud means that companies employing legacy cybersecurity solutions “no longer control the infrastructure that employees are utilizing”. Additionally, the Internet of Things allows connectivity to more devices, which provides “a much larger surface of attack for the average consumer”.

The next wave of technological advancements harness the powers of machine learning to proactively neutralize new threats and the blockchain protocol to provide enhanced cryptographic techniques to secure networks. Cylance offers multiple products and services including CylancePROTECT a proactive machine learning platform that predicts previously un-detected malware and continuously learns to respond to new threats by “training” on large data sets. While Everchain, a FinTech startup based out of Philadelphia, provides enterprise and mobile solution that utilizes blockchain technology to secure transactions and communications in the cloud. The powerful combination of an influx of investor dollars and the continuously evolving cyber threat landscape, means lots of innovators will be compelled to devote time and effort to growing cybersecurity businesses.

Resources For Entrepreneurs

For a startup, an expensive cyber defense may not be your highest priority when you want to meet milestones and grow your business. A recent article in Entrepreneur highlights four steps that a company can take to enhance their cybersecurity posture in today’s threat environment. Additionally, every entrepreneur should be aware of the Top 10 Cyber Threat List, which is published by Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP) a not-for-profit organization that provides information about software security solutions. For a deeper look into what actions an entrepreneur can take, we turned to Ngozi Nwaneri, a first-year MBA Candidate at Wharton, who has studied information security and worked in private equity and financial services to develop an Entrepreneur’s Primer for Cybersecurity (see below). We would love to get your feedback as we periodically update this primer so it can continue to be useful as new techniques, policies and threats emerge.

fields.description: Steve sits down with Laura Forth, Managing Director of College CFO, a student-driven organization that provides resources to educate students about personal finance.
fields.title: Student-Driven Financial Empowerment: Interview with College CFO
fields.text:
The following is a Q&A excerpt between Steve Weiner, Co-Founder of Wharton FinTech, and Laura Forth, Managing Director of College CFO.

College CFO is a student-driven organization that provides resources to educate students about budgeting, student loans, interviewing, investing, credit cards and much more.

Tell us about College CFO and how it’s differentiated in the financial education space?

College CFO is a company that’s tailored for college students that are transitioning from the safety net of college to the real world after graduation. By the time you graduate, students already need to have a good credit score, which means that they already need to have been building credit using a credit card or a small student loan. As soon as students begin going through this transition, they are hit with student loan repayments, which they may or may not be ready for. They’re going to be receiving paychecks that subtract unknown kinds of taxes from their salary. They will have to do their own taxes for the first time.

Higher education is not doing a very good job of preparing students for these life skills. College CFO tries to fill the gap in students' financial education. One of the ways that we do that is through our nine-module Financial Empowerment Course. Each module takes about 30 minutes to complete, and goes over everything from student loans, to investing, to identity theft. Upon completion of the course, students receive the Financial Empowerment Badge, a certification that they can affix to their resume or LinkedIn profile.

College CFO’s resources also make a direct connection between financial literacy and early career success. While money management skills will benefit students’ finances, there is research to support that financially literate employees are perceived as being more engaged and productive by employers.

College CFO also has a suite of supplemental tools that support the course content. We have the Student Loan Snapshot tool that pulls all student loan information together into one dashboard. Personalized job boards, resume keyword analysis, and other tools help make a purchasing a College CFO membership an easy decision.

Why do you think it’s the right time to tackle financial education? Is this a really big problem in the U.S. right now?

Student loan debt in the U.S. is roughly $1.3 trillion. 65% of students graduating from college hold student debt at an average of about $30,000. That’s the same percentage (65%) of students that report misunderstanding their student loan requirements. There is a severe lack of education about personal finances in this country, but especially when it comes to paying for college. Parents and students alike are unprepared to pay the ever increasing cost of higher education. College CFO is focusing on financial literacy education for college students so that they don't have to carry the burden of paying for their diplomas for the rest of their lives. Contrary to those who say that millennials enjoy freeloading off their parents, we believe that students crave financial independence and are not being given the right resources to achieve it. It’s our mission to be that resource.

What are some of the common misunderstandings that your customers have about financial literacy?

One misunderstanding among both students and parents is that financial understanding will just happen on it’s own. We find that most of our members are uncomfortable talking about money in general. We see that lack of communication amongst peers and between students and their parents. Unfortunately when there is no communication, learning about finances often happens as the result of avoidable mistakes.

Another misunderstanding is about the benefits of investing savings. This generation grew up during the financial crisis seeing first-hand what can happen when markets fail. There is widespread misunderstanding about why it’s important to save early and invest intelligently. This problem is compounded by the fact that recent graduates’ first long-term savings account is often a 401k or IRA. When they are in their early twenties, retirement feels like it’s never going to reach them. We’re trying to tackle a lot of those misconceptions with education.

How are you overcoming the challenge that people don't like talking about money and finances?

College CFO is providing tools for students and parents that will help them form a budget and talk about investing. One of our most popular tools is our Beer Budget Envelope game. It works like this: Students and parents write down everything that they can spend money on for five minutes. Then they go over every line item together. This simple exercise is usually eye-opening for both sides. The next step is figuring out how much money the students can spend over the course of a semester. Once they figure out their top line, students and parents allocate money in a series of envelopes, each for a different expense. Parents are then encouraged to talk about potential rewards if the student sticks to a budget or consequences if they cannot. Going through this exercise helps students and parents share expectations and opens up lines of communication.

How did you get started at College CFO?

The founder of College CFO, Susan Bruno, is a friend’s mother. She founded a company called DivaCFO, which provided financial resources to women who were going through financial change as a result of divorce, debt, disaster, etc. DivaCFO had college interns who revealed to Susan that they didn’t understand the resources that they were giving these women. Susan decided to expand her mission to include college students and recent graduates. I was brought on as an intern to build the original website for what was then called ‘CollegeDivaCFO’. Once the website was built, I began providing content. Once the content was written, we needed someone to market it. About six months ago, we formed a partnership with iGrad, a financial literacy education provider. With iGrad’s help we are now able to offer an expanding suite of tools and educational resources. I’m am very excited about College CFO’s increasing ability to educate students and graduates about personal finance.

How can people get involved and help College CFO?

The best way that you can help College CFO is by spreading the word. Right now, we are trying to expand the number of people that our education is reaching. The best way that you can help is by actively educating yourself with our tools and sharing your experience. It’s easier than you think, we promise!

What advantages do you see to being a “virtual classroom”?

Thanks to iGrad’s help, College CFO is an entirely online platform. We have very strong social media content and a supplemental blog where we publish student atrticles about what they think about money, testimonials from students who have gone through our program and our Virtual Mentor Series where we use excerpts from Richard Branson's book The Virgin Way. One of Richard’s philanthropic missions is financial literacy and he believes that College CFO is doing good work in this space. We are looking forward to sharing more of his content in the future.

What’s next for College CFO?

College CFO wants find out from our members what kind of products they are looking for next. Our number one goal is always to provide members with relevant tools for their success. Leveraging feedback to yield new products and improvements is an important part of our future. One thing that we are considering is grouping our course content around objective rather than subject. So instead of a module about credit reporting, a group of modules around buying your first car. That may be something that we pursue, but I can’t give away too much right now. As always, we will continue improve our products to make them better for our members.

fields.description: A recap of Wharton FinTech's FinTech industry trek to the San Francisco Bay area. Highlights include visits to Wealthfront, Coinbase, Square, Ripple, Citi Ventures and NerdWallet.
fields.title: Wharton FinTech Goes West: Industry Trek to the Bay Area
fields.text:
For two sunny days in late February, students from Wharton FinTech visited the San Francisco Bay area for our second FinTech Industry Trek. Building off the successful trip to New York City’s Silicon Alley, we ventured out of the icy northeast and caught up with some of the world’s most exciting FinTech startups. The trek was oversubscribed with 24 participants and included 11 company visits in San Francisco and two in Palo Alto. The following is a brief rundown of our itinerary - including some tidbits of advice that the founders, investors and operators had for students and aspiring entrepreneurs.

Asset Management

Personal Capital seeks to provide better financial services to consumers with a client-centric business model that with a client-centric business model that combines a human advisor with financial software.

Life advice: Bill Harris, Founder and CEO of Personal Capital, suggested that young entrepreneurs should “know your own strengths and weaknesses. It’s ok to have weaknesses as long as you find team members that supplement the weaknesses.”

Wealthfront is an algorithmic wealth management platform that aims to provide investors with investment products that are low on both cost and human intervention. They also offer tax-loss harvesting and Single-Stock-Diversification, helping technology employees intelligently diversifty the exposure they have to their respective companies.

Life advice: If you are thinking about working at a startup check out the list of mid-sized start-up companies compiled annually by Wealthfront Chairman and Co-founder, Andy Rachleff. If you’re in the Philadelphia area, don’t miss our interview with Andy live at Wharton on April 10th.

Cryptocurrency

Chain is an enterprise-grade blockchain infrastructure company that enables developers to build on the internet’s open financial protocol. Their goal is “to make it so simple, secure, and intuitive to build with the bitcoin protocol that ever-greater numbers of creative entrepreneurs and enterprises launch products that could not have existed just a few years ago.”

Life advice: Adam Ludwin, Founder and CEO of Chain, talked about the importance of founders who are creating new technology to focus on “serving people and being humble.”

Coinbase is a bitcoin services company that serves 24 different countries and over 2.5 million consumer bitcoin wallets (the most in the world). Coinbase recently opened a bitcoin exchange in the US and had received the most venture funding amongst cyrptocurrency startups until the recent funding round closed by 21, Inc.

Ripple Labs is a technology startup that developed the Ripple protocol, which enables disparate financial institutions and payment networks to communicate on a simplly, safely and openly.

Data

Mattermark is the definitive source for information about startups and private companies, with information sourced from multiple databases and information providers.

Life advice: Mattermark CTO, Kevin Morrill, believes that more wealth will be created in the private markets than the public markets in the future, because companies are less willing to go public and deal with transactional investors and SEC regulations. He also suggested picking up The Possibilities of Organizations by Barry Oshry for a good read on organizational and leadership development.

AltX aims to become the most accurate and comprehensive database of information on alternative investment managers. The firm wants to research ways to match funds with the right investors, not only by strategy and return profiles, but by behavioral characteristics as well.

Education

NerdWallet is a financial education website that aims to be the neutral party in providing information on financial products like credit cards and insurance to customers. NerdWallet’s revenue model is structured around referral fees from financial institutions who issue the financial products.

Life advice: According to NerdWallet CEO Tim Chen, who was a finalist for EY’s 2014 Entrepreneur of the Year, “consumer mindshare and trust is more important than having a specific business model.”

Lending

Prosper is a leader in the peer-to-peer lending space. Its platform connects investors willing to extend loans to entrepreneurs and other borrowers that are lower than pay day lender and traditional institutional rates.

Life advice: Ron Suber, President of Prosper, recommends Daniel Goleman’s Emotional Intelligence for learning one of the most important professional and personal traits that many people neglect.

Payments

Braintree is a collective of online payment platforms that accepts Paypal, Apple Pay, Bitcoin, Venmo and traditional cards. The company was acquired by Payal in late 2013 and has been rapidly evolving to support payments processed through companies such as OpenTable, StubHub, Uber and Airbnb.

Square, the company behind products like Square Cash, Square Order, Square Capital and Square Feedback, emphasized the culture difference between Square and other companies. The vibe at the company is one of transparency, camaraderie and open-mindedness.

Stripe is a developer-friendly platform for accepting payments online and in mobile apps. Stripe processes billions of dollars per year for companies such as Kickstarter, Lyft, Reddit, Shopify, TaskRabbit and Twitter.

Life advice: Stripe’s managers emphasized the importance of being a self-starter and driving your own workstreams and projects. “There’s so much work that needs to be done and so many battles that have to be fought at a young company such as Stripe”, one manager told us. “Our teams are expected to go out there and fight these battles with little oversight or direction.”

Venture

Citi Ventures was launched five years ago with six investment professionals. The team is positioning itself between corporate and financial VCs and only invests in companies that makes strategic sense for Citi. The team sees the following as enduring themes: enterprise security, data analytics, financial services & technology and commerce and payments.

Life advice: The Citi Ventures team recommends that aspiring venture capitalists should develop deep domain knowledge, work at a startup in a field that they are interested in and potentially do some pro-bono work for a fund in order to develop a track record of experience.

Looking Forward

We feel really grateful to have had the opportunity to meet with such exciting companies on the two days we were in the Bay Area. It is clear that FinTech companies are attracting some of the brightest talent in the Bay Area and it will be exciting to see how these companies evolve in the future. Thank you to all the founders and execs that took time to speak with our group - we can’t wait to see all the success you have in the future!

fields.description: Daniel sits down with Matt Carey, Founder of retirement spending startup, Abaris, a first of its kind online marketplace for annuities that sells directly to consumers.
fields.title: Abaris Financial and the Revolution in Retirement Spending
fields.text:
The following is an interview between Daniel McAuley, Co-Founder of Wharton FinTech, and Matt Carey, Co-Founder of Abaris Financial. This interview took place March 22, 2015.

Abaris is a first of its kind online marketplace for annuities that sells directly to consumers. Their initial focus is on Deferred Income Annuities (DIAs), a product that can protect retirees against longevity risk.

Annuities are something that a lot of people may not be familiar with. Can you start by giving us a little background on Abaris and your product?

Let’s start with annuities. An annuity is a recurring form of income that lasts for your entire life. Examples of annuities that most people are familiar with are Social Security and corporate pensions. Social Security is an annuity provided by the government and pensions are an annuity provided by an employer. An annuity is provided by an insurance company and you purchase it yourself. Maybe it helps to provide an example. Let’s say I’m 55 today, I want my annuity to start paying me at age 75. $10,000 today could buy you as much as $1,900 a year, every year starting at 75 for as long as you live. And that’s really important, that last part: as long as you live. You no longer have to worry about whether you live to 85, 90 or 95. You want to live as long as you’re healthy and happy and you don’t have to worry anymore about your money running out. These types of products are underwritten by large insurers, household names like MetLife, Lincoln Financial, The Principal, or MassMutual, so buyers can have confidence that income will be there when they retire. We’re not there yet, but we’re working to become appointed with all of these insurers.

Abaris is the platform where people can actually purchase these products. Right now, you have to go through individual insurance agents who might not be appointed to sell a lot of different insurance carriers’ policies. We are able to quote and sell a majority of the market, but we’re not creating these products. What we’re doing is providing people the place to learn about annuities, compare different insurers’ side-by-side and then complete the purchase if they decide to buy. We’re doing kind of like what Orbitz has done for flights or what Coverhound is doing right now for auto insurance.

Why is retirement spending such an important problem to solve and why isn’t much being done about it?

It’s important to solve because in almost every case retirees today are either overspending and running out of money or underspending and forgoing the lifestyle they could have had. In addition, no matter what happens, retirees are losing a lot of peace of mind along the way.

I think there are two reasons though why more hasn’t been done to solve it. The first is that getting people to save for retirement is still an unsolved problem. In order to develop solutions for better retirement spending you first need to make sure that you’ve saved enough and figuring out how to get people to save more and invest it appropriately is really challenging. Only recently have you started to see some big developments with companies like Wealthfront or Betterment getting people to do a better job saving and putting that money away and kind of forgetting about it and investing it in a really smart, tax efficient, behaviorally sound way. The markets are still largely focused, for a good reason, on getting people to save enough, so the idea of retirement spending is only starting to be talked about. The innovation is only starting and we’re at the forefront of that. The second reason we haven’t seen as much being done about it is because of the demographic. Customers who buy DIAs tend to be nearing retirement, so between ages 50 and 65. And only recently has Internet usage and comfort with online purchasing reached a point where the market was ready for this. If you look, for example, about where Facebook’s domestic user growth is coming from, it’s basically the baby boomers and those who are a little bit younger. They’re doing a lot more online these days than just checking e-mails. So now we feel like it’s finally the time to launch this product because our customers feel comfortable with a process that is partially online, especially at the beginning of the sales funnel.

What do you see as Abaris’ main advantages when compared to insurance agents and other competitors?

We have a few advantages over insurance agents who are the ones selling most of the policies today and the first of those is education. At the moment, annuities are sold, not bought. What that implies is that it requires really pushy sales tactics and often times a “fear driven” sales approach to get people to purchase annuities. We don’t think that, in this day and age, people should be buying because they are psychologically forced into a corner. What we’re doing is providing everyone with information about when it makes sense to purchase a DIA but also when it doesn’t, and that is pretty unique in this market. Second, we offer people the ability to compare different product offerings, and I talked about that a little bit earlier but right now your insurance agent might only be appointed with one insurance carrier and they’re just going to try and sell you that product. But you never know if you’re getting the best price, if you’re getting an annuity from an insurer that is very safe with a high credit rating, and the trade off you’re making between price and credit rating, those sorts of things. So comparison is not something that really exists today and we’re providing it and that’s a huge value proposition to the consumer. Lastly, our cost structure is lower, so our incentive is to make sure that you get the best price, not to sell you a product where we get paid the highest commission, and that also is a big difference. So you can be sure that we have your best interests in mind when you’re on our platform.

There are a lot of mental biases that come along with consumer financial products specifically. What is Abaris doing to help consumers overcome these hurdles and where do you see your biggest challenges?

That’s a great question and something we’ve been focused on since the beginning. The first advisor we brought on is a professor by the name of Hal Hershfield. Hal is a Stanford Ph.D. and teaches at UCLA, and his focus is on the type of issues you mentioned. The biggest psychological issue here is present bias. In order to purchase one of these products, you basically have to say “alright I’m going to take money that I could spend today and put it in a product that’s not going to start benefiting me for a long time into the future.” And that requires a lot of foresight and we know from psychology that that can be challenging. What Hal has done in his research is demonstrate that if you show someone an aged version of their own face, they are much more likely to save. We’re going to incorporate things like that into our platform so people can combat this present bias. Another thing we’re dealing with is, and the annuity market has very much had a challenge with this, is choice overload. We wish the market were as simple as, “hey I want an annuity right now that starts paying me at age 70 or 75 or 80 and I want it to be inflation-protected the whole time and that’s that. Tell me what I should buy.” But right now products aren’t that simple. The market has added a lot of complexity and customization and what we’ve tried to do is essentially say, “alright, tell us a little bit of information about yourself and we’ll suggest some default options so that you’re not overloaded with all these choices and, if you want, you can customize that but we’ll tell you why we chose these default options.” We think it’s really important to get people to actually feel comfortable with what they’re doing.

This is all really cool, innovative and exciting, and it sounds like it’s very good for the consumer. Are the existing insurance companies and the other players in the annuity space supportive of what you’re doing or are you getting pushback from entrenched interests?

I think I would describe it as more support than push back. From the insurance carrier’s perspective this is another channel for them, another way for them to get their products into consumers’ hands. I don’t think it’s a secret that the insurance industry has been a bit behind in terms of innovating on distribution, underwriting and marketing. Now what we’re starting to see is a lot of interest in the insurance community to do more because their customer base is shifting in terms of who is buying these products. The average 50 year old wasn’t thinking about this at all ten years ago and now they certainly are. Everyone, carriers especially, see the opportunity and want to figure out how they can fit this in both right now and as part of their future product roadmap.

Annuities are just one of many financial products specifically. Where do you see opportunities for Abaris to apply this model that you’ve developed to other markets or products?

If you think about how quickly pensions have gone away over the last three decades and how much less of someone’s total spending needs that Social Security actually provides than it used to, you realize that we’ve got a huge opportunity in DIAs alone. In many cases, this product is the one that should be filling that gap and it is not really today in terms of sales volume. So we think there is a really large opportunity to get this product in more people’s hands. That’s our focus for the near and medium term. One way we’re thinking about innovating further in this market is by making it easier for people to purchase these products in low dollar amounts on a recurring basis. Right now, you have to save up 10, 20 or 50 thousand dollars before you buy one of these and it’s pretty challenging for folks to make that big of a decision and it’s not really how they think about their money. Right now, every two weeks, money comes out of your paycheck to go to your 401(k). There’s no reason why in the future some of the money you’re taking out of your paycheck for your 401(k) can’t go straight into an annuity and fund your DIA on a recurring basis. By expressing it in terms of monthly income, people can see actually how much they’re saving for retirement.

What advice do you have for aspiring FinTech entrepreneurs out there, particularly MBAs that may not have technical experience?

I think the key is to go after a market you know. I chose this market, for example, because I worked on retirement policy at the Treasury Department at a time when there was a lot happening in this area. I got to learn the space pretty well and I saw an opportunity to bring technology into the market. I think you’re always going to have the easiest time pursuing a startup in an area that you know really well because otherwise there are inevitably going to be things that surprise you along the way. I’d say that’s the biggest piece of advice I have. At the same time, I think financial services and insurance are certainly behind the curve in adopting technology. I think that there are lots of opportunities right now to go out there and find a niche, carve it out, acquire customers and really build a profitable growing business.

That’s great advice. Before we close do you have any last words you’d like to leave us with?

Two things. The first is a huge thank you to you and Steve and the rest of Wharton FinTech. This group didn’t exist during my first year at Wharton and in less than a year’s time it’s already made a huge impact on innovation in financial services, not just at Wharton but in the broader FinTech community. You guys have really established yourselves as thought leaders and that’s great for the school and the industry. Second, this issue we’re talking about is a really big one and I think people are starting to understand how big it really is. When Social Security was created you had people living maybe five or seven years into retirement. Now, on average, a 65 year old is going to live to about 88 and by the time we’re ready to retire that number could be well into the 90s. And what this means is that if you’re living for 30 years post-retirement you really having to think a lot harder and more seriously than in the past about how you’re going to accumulate enough money to live and then how you can be more sophisticated in spending that money down. We’re super excited about what we’re doing because we think that this is just the beginning. There’s going to be a lot more innovation in the space and we feel like this will be a transformational couple of decades for retirement spending.

fields.description: Sarah explores how fintech companies are creating social impact, increasing financial inclusion and challenging traditional definitions of underbanked.
fields.title: How FinTech Reimagines the Meaning of "Underbanked"
fields.text:
Ask what “FinTech” means to someone in social impact, and I can almost guarantee that his or her answer is “financial inclusion”. It’s a term more popular in the social impact world, and for all intents and purposes it’s synonymous with FinTech for people in impact investing, international development and elsewhere in the space where technology bridges the infrastructure gaps that prevent access to banks in the first place. From microfinance to mobile payments to alternative loan services, FinTech has already proven itself a pillar of the social impact world, capable of fulfilling the so-called triple bottom line: people, planet and profits.

FinTech + Social Impact = Financial Inclusion

Financial inclusion is defined by the Center for Financial Inclusion as “A state in which all people who can use them have access to a full suite of quality financial services, provided at affordable prices, in a convenient manner, and with dignity for the clients. Financial services are delivered by a range of providers, most of them private, and reach everyone who can use them, including disabled, poor, rural, and other excluded populations.” The term was first used in 1997, according to the Financial Inclusion Commission, and has since been used to describe efforts to give financial access to the traditionally unbanked or underbanked.

From my perspective, it’s easy to see how FinTech fits into social impact. I’ve spent quite a bit of time researching and sourcing companies with the Wharton Social Venture Fund (a student-run impact investing fund), and individually in Latin America, where I spent my last summer looking into how social enterprises measure impact. I’ve also been fortunate enough to be exposed to quite a number of financial inclusion ventures through my work as a Fellow for Wharton’s Social Impact Initiative, and through my own career search. As I’ve become more familiar with the social impact sector and financial technology as a tool, I’ve come to recognize financial inclusion as the intersection of the potential of FinTech and social impact.

What makes FinTech so important to Social Impact?

Shifting perceptions and uses of both new and traditional financial services - like M-Pesa, CommonBond, and even “traditional” microfinance - are exactly what makes FinTech so crucial to the social impact space. In the most basic terms, people are coming to expect more and better quality products and services from the finance industry: FinTech is bridging the gap between current offerings and expectations by fostering innovation on both the provider and consumer end of the spectrum. Startups such as those mentioned above, then, are thinking about what’s possible in terms of changes to existing financial structures: i.e., fundamental shifts in how consumers interact with their money and with financial institutions.

Some of the more technical groups in FinTech are focused on the possibilities of the blockchain, the disintermediation of the banking services and, of course, data and analytics.

Social impactors have their eyes on the same trends, but with a distinct perspective: they’re wondering how FinTech – and the innovations and trends thereto – can be harnessed to benefit the underserved. Now, definitions of who fits into that “underserved” market vary widely; social impact is still relatively young as an industry, after all, and it’s still going through some growing pains. Trends like micro-loans and mobile payments are often associated with rural populations in the developing world, who we might see as the traditionally “underserved” market.

The interesting thing about FinTech, however, is that in a sense all of us are underserved. FinTech isn’t just about solving problems at the base of the pyramid or in just the developing world: it’s about making financial technology, and more importantly, financial access, available to everyone, everywhere.

Redefining the Under and Unbanked

Allow me to demonstrate with the most pertinent example. When we hear “unbanked” and “underbanked” we tend to think of exactly those populations I mentioned earlier: rural, poor, and outside of the developing world. But the fact is 7.7% of US households were unbanked and 20% were underbanked in 2013, according to the FDIC. That’s not a negligible number by any means. Data on the penetration of retirement plans – 401(k)s, IRAs, etc. – is equally as dismal: only 16% of American workers have 401(k)s, and 40.4% have IRAs, according to ICI Global. Worst of all, about one-third of those with retirement accounts haven’t even started saving. Talk about an opportunity for FinTech!

Mobile payments technology is perhaps the most well known implementation of FinTech in social impact, with companies such as M-PESA, Kifiya and Venmo swiftly and drastically altering the financial landscape in both the developing and developed worlds. In other words, physical cash is not necessarily king anymore. Alternative loan and refinancing services – think Wharton startups CommonBond or Nexu – have also been proliferating widely across incomes, geographies and demographics. And who can forget Bitcoin, the cryptocurrency that is fundamentally changing the definition of access and ownership of monetary value.

Going Forward

Clearly, financial access, tools, literacy and, most importantly, financial freedom are social issues that span the globe. FinTech has enabled “social impact” upon each of these factors through innovation in payments and financial services. However, I believe FinTech’s biggest social impact potential has yet to be realized. The approach so far has been relatively piecemeal (by which I mean individual solutions to portions of the overall problem) and is only the first step. I believe FinTech’s real impact is going to be the ability to give anyone – from the unbanked farmer in Ecuador to the savvy investor on Wall Street – access to and, more importantly, control over their financial resources. In my personal opinion, FinTech, in conjunction with social impact, is going to mean the end of banks as we know them - a complete override of the financial sector. This will revolutionize how we handle our money and empower individuals to decide how they will save, invest and spend.

Wharton is already leading the discussion on multiple fronts with Wharton FinTech, the financial inclusion team in the Wharton Social Venture Fund and their Leadership and Diversity for Innovation Program in partnership with Women’s World Banking, Credit Suisse and Cisco. FinTech’s role in social impact still has a ways to go, but I think it’s safe to say Wharton is at the front of the wave.
